resources.string: This is the URL that will be used when the search button is pressed, and will be joined with the search keywords to form an actual URL. The search button can only be used when this is set.\nExample: https://example.com/search?q=
The source code of this app is available at https://github.com/sls1005/FundamentalBrowser, under the MIT Licence.

Remove spaces and linebreaks when loading a URL
It is recommended to turn this on.
Show button for running input as a script
This only works if JavaScript is enabled.
Use customised user agent

When disabled or not set, the default will be used.\n\nWarning: Please note that the use of highly customised user agent may result in privacy-related issues as described in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231#section-9.7 .
Desktop mode

This is implemented by changing the user agent of this browser and thus can result in privacy-related issues as described in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231#section-9.7 .\nIf this doesn\'t work, please consider using a custom user agent. See below for more information about customised user agents.
Add a language

This specifies the preferred languages of webpages, not the language of the UI.
When disabled, the default will be used. If enabled but not set, no language tag will be sent.
If this doesn't work, please consider changing the language of this app. If your device supports doing so, the option for changing the language of this application will appear in the device settings.
A website may ignore this.

Warning: Please note that the use of highly customized language tags may result in privacy-related issues as described in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231#section-9.7 .
Clear log before running a script

Do you want to follow the redirection to load the page of ‘%1$s’?
Show advanced developer tools in the menu and submenus of this application.

Even if this is disabled, you can still use common developer tools such as the JavaScript console (if it is enabled) and the log, and can still view the source code of a web page or the certificate of a website. This option currently only covers less common tools.
Disable dynamic colours

When this is turned on and the theme of this app is set to a theme other than the default, the colours of the UI of this app will not change according to system settings. There is, however, no guarantee that the colours would change according to system settings while this is turned off.
Select a language
The higher the weight, the higher the priority is. A language with higher priority is considered preferred. Default means highest priority.

View the privacy policy
Privacy Policy

1. This is a notice, not a legal document.

2. When using this app, some of the information you provide, possibly including, but not limited to, a customised so-called ‘user agent’ or user-selected language tags, may be stored in the device by this app. Such data may be stored unencrypted.

3. When the user visits a website by using this app, some information provided by the user, notably a customised user agent or user-selected language tags, may be sent to the website. Depending on the protocol, such data may be sent unencrypted.

4. Please note that, if you enable for your device the feature called ‘live threat protection’ in the settings of your device, certain data resulted from your online activities and the use of this application may be obtained by the entity that provides such security-related service for your device. See https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/master/android_webview/browser/safe_browsing/README.md for more information. (The link points to the description of a feature of your device, not necessarily related with this app.)

5. This application itself will not track you, but it also will not prevent anyone or anything from tracking you on the net.

6. For more details about how this application collects and uses information, please see the source code of this application.
Do you want to manually set the language tags?
Do you want to open this URL with another application?
Warning: you are the one responsible for any damage caused by this action, so please read the URL/URI carefully, especially if it starts with ‘intent:’.
Do you want to load the page of ‘%1$s’?
1. UI
i. The URL bar

The URL bar of this app is a little different from that of other browsers. It is still the place where the URL is displayed or edited, but now it is usually hidden and only shows up when the user needs it.

When you need to see the URL bar, tap on the ‘://’ symbol if it is present in the top bar, or use the ‘Show/hide URL bar’ or ‘Edit URL’ option from the menu that is opened by tapping the three-dot icon in the top bar. Tapping the ‘://’ symbol once again (if it is present) will close the URL bar if it is already opened.

The URL bar allows multiline editing, that is, text that is too long will be wrapped to the next line. This makes it easier to view and edit when the URL is very long.

There are several buttons at the bottom of the URL bar. Those are:

Load: load the web page corresponding to a given URL. Unlike the ‘Search’ button, this does not do search.

Search: search the web by using the text in the URL field as keywords. Only usable if the ‘search URL’ is set. Unlike the ‘Load’ button, this will not load a URL but… will search for it.

Copy: copy the text in the URL field, or the selected text in the URL field, if any.

Paste: paste the text to the URL field, either at the end of text or at the selected position if any text is selected.

Clear: clear the URL field, removing all text.

Restore: replace any text in the URL field with a previously loaded URL. This can also be used if the field is empty, in which case the previously loaded URL will still be restored, if any.

Edit: show the UI for editing the URL. It uses the entire screen to display the URL.

Decode: decode the URL if it is pct-encoded. See https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3986 for more details about pct-encoding.

Close: close the URL bar.
ii. The main window
This is where the web page is displayed.\n
iii. The log

The log is a record of the web requests this app has made, including the requests for images, scripts, data (e.g., JSON) and other kinds of resources. It also contains the output of each script that has been run.

To open the log, use the ‘view log’ option from the option menu. The option is only available if there is anything in the log.

Each request-related entry consists of:
 (1) the method, e.g., GET.
 (2) if it is the result of a redirection, a string that indicates so.
 (3) the URL associated with that request.

To search for a specific record in the log, use the ‘Search in log’ option from the option menu. The option will be available when you open the menu while the log is opened.

Using the back button of the device (or an equivalent gesture) will close the log.
2. Usage
i. Load a URL
To load a URL, paste it to the URL field and then tap ‘Load’.\n
ii. Search the web
To do search, firstly set the search URL in settings and enter the keyword, and then tap ‘Search’.\n
iii. Search a web page
To do search in a web page, use the ‘search content’ option from the option menu (only available if any page is loaded).\n
iv. View the source code

To see the source code of a web page, add ‘view-source:’ to the start of the URL that points to it. For example: ‘view-source:https://example.com/index.html’. This usage is supported through the framework.

Alternatively, you can use the ‘view the source code of this page’ option hidden in the submenu that is opened by tapping the three-dot icon and then tapping ‘more’. You may set in the settings the source viewer implementation that will perform this task. The default is ‘native’, which means the task is processed by the framework. However, if it doesn't work on your device, you may instead set it to ‘alternative’, which means that this app will use a different approach to do that.

To search in the source code, you may use the ‘search content’ option as if it were a normal web page. This is currently only supported if you are using the ‘native’ approach.
v. Console and REPL

To use the console and REPL features, input some code (should normally be JS code) into the URL field and use the ‘Run’ button (enabled in settings) to execute it. The execution of such code, even in the console mode, is never handled by this app, but by the framework or system. This app only implemented the logic to display the log messages.\n
vi. Logging
The ‘foreground logging’ feature gives you some meta-information about the page you are reading. The format of it is the same as that of a log entry. See above for more details.\n
vii. Using this app as a generalised intent sender or activity launcher

By using some code that looks like ‘location.href="intent:#Intent;...;end"’, you can utilise this app as a generalised intent sender and activity launcher (by specifying ‘action’, ‘component’, etc. in the form of text), with the restriction that, the intent can only be sent to an app other than this application. For security concerns, this app will refuse to send such an intent if it detects its own package name in the URI or intent, in which case it can show an error message and might not log.

Intent scheme URIs are half-supported by this app. That is to say, they will usually be processed correctly, but this app usually doesn't check if a URI is an ‘intent:’ URI, except when trying to protect itself from intent-based attacks. (See https://www.mbsd.jp/Whitepaper/IntentScheme.pdf for information about this issue.)

Instead, `intent:` URIs will be treated as if they were URIs of unrecognised schemes (such as ‘abc://’), for any of which this app will ask the user whether to launch an intent, except in the specific situations mentioned above.
viii. Locally loading and debugging HTML

To locally load and debug a piece of HTML code, you may load it as a data: URI (by prefixing it with ‘data:text/html,’ or ‘data:,’). This usage is half-supported by this application through the framework.\n\nAlternatively, you may use the ‘Load HTML code’ option in the submenu that is opened by tapping the three-dot icon and then tapping ‘more’. You must enable the ‘advanced developer tools’ option in the settings of this app in order to see the option in the submenu. If you use this method, this app will automatically convert the HTML code into a data URI and present it in the URL field. The data URI will be pct-encoded, which means you may load it into another browser that supports doing so. The ‘Decode’ button below the URL field can be used to decode the pct-encoded string and restore the HTML code.
